message.content:
cs.LG, cs.GT, cs.MA, cs.DS, cs.AI

The paper deals with a dynamic pricing problem and proposes a policy based on the likelihood ratio test. This suggests that the paper is likely to belong to the sub-category of machine learning (cs.LG) as it deals with learning from data. The problem also involves uncertainty in demand models, which suggests that it could belong to the sub-category of game theory (cs.GT) as it deals with decision-making in uncertain environments. The paper formulates the problem as a multi-armed bandit with dependent arms, which suggests that it could belong to the sub-category of multi-armed bandits (cs.MA). The paper also involves the analysis of regret, which suggests that it could belong to the sub-category of data structures and algorithms (cs.DS). Finally, the paper proposes a dynamic pricing policy, which suggests that it could belong to the sub-category of artificial intelligence (cs.AI) as it deals with decision-making in an intelligent manner.
